data.name: counting in dot notation
data.description:
In forestry, when counting treesðŸŒ²ðŸŒ³ðŸŒ²ðŸŒ³, to spare paper we use 'dot' notation, one dot for one to four and then join the dots from 5 to 10 :
```
. -> 1
: -> 2
:. -> 3
:: -> 4
|: -> 5
âŸ” -> 6
âŠ“ -> 7
â˜ -> 8
â§„ -> 9
â˜’ -> 10
```

We always finish a jointed square â˜’ before starting a new one so the result is easily readable ( 34 -> â˜’â˜’â˜’::)

## your challenge

write a function **write** that takes a positive integer and turns it into a string representing this number in dot notation, and a function **read** that does the opposite

if the number is 0 or below, the write method shall return an empty string "" *(will never be below 0 in C++ or typed languages using unsigned int)*

if the dot notation is invalid (not a sequel of â˜’ followed by a valid dot "digit") the read method shall return 0
```js
write(19) === 'â˜’â§„'
read('â˜’â˜’â˜’:.') === 33
write(-5) === ''
read('::â˜’') === 0
```

the exact symbols of the previous list will be used, and you can access a list of them as strings in the list **dictionary** provided in the solution template. 

> Beware that some digits (eg 3 -> `:.`) use 2 ASCII chars !

> (in C++) beware that unicode digits like â˜’ are 3 chars long!
> you should be able to deal with it

> Beware that indexes of the dictionary are not reflective of the digit

```js
dictionary[0] == '.' // 1
dictionary[3] == '::' // 4
dictionary[9] == 'â˜’' // 10
```

> âš ï¸ in response to comments, return values expected
> for invalid arguments have been changed from false to
> '' (empty string) for write and 0 for read.
> My apologies if your answer is not valid  
> due to this breaking change
